run_a.lens: Freud Ch III+V (Civilization and Its Discontents: instinctual renunciation, civilizational demands, aggression, narcissism of minor differences)

run_b.lens: Flow Ch 4 (Conditions of Flow: challenge-skill balance, feedback, goals, control, autotelic context, anomie, alienation)

convergent_themes.theme: Value before demand -- the platform must give before it takes at every phase entry
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: works-001 (Graduate Instinctual Renunciation) prescribes that platform value must precede every disclosure demand. ds-ui-1830-001 (Discovery Earnings Estimator Card) shows earnings data before any sign-up. Freud's principle: 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.'
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: works-006 (Value-Before-Investment as Flow Entry Gate) prescribes showing real listings before any account creation. ds-ui-1831-001 (Progressive Density Listing Card) delivers rich search results without authentication. User stories: 'Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.'
convergent_themes.implication: Both independent theoretical frameworks -- Freud's instinctual economics and Csikszentmihalyi's flow prerequisites -- arrive at the same prescription: zero-ask discovery. This convergence from two unrelated disciplines elevates value-before-the-ask from a UX best practice to a structurally necessary design requirement. Implementation: neither journey should ever present a gate (registration, information request, commitment) before demonstrating concrete value.

convergent_themes.theme: Structured proposals as trust-enabling artifacts that serve both sides of the marketplace
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: works-003 (Structure Guest Proposals as Civilizational Compliance Signals) + ds-ui-1830-004 (Proposal Review Card with Trust-First Architecture). A well-formed proposal demonstrates the guest has submitted to marketplace rules, reducing the host's instinctual distrust. Trust zone placed above terms zone.
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: works-003 (Challenge-Skill Calibration for Proposal Creation) + ds-ui-1831-004 (Pre-Populated Proposal Builder with Host Preview). Pre-populated fields reduce the guest's self-consciousness (a flow inhibitor) and produce higher-quality proposals that activate hosts faster.
convergent_themes.implication: The proposal is the single most important cross-activation artifact in the marketplace. Run A reveals WHY the host needs structured proposals (stranger-threat resolution). Run B reveals WHY the guest needs pre-populated proposals (self-consciousness reduction). Together they form a complete design specification: pre-populate on the guest side to reduce anxiety AND structure the output for trust-first scanning on the host side. The proposal form and proposal review card should be designed as a matched pair.

convergent_themes.theme: The Stays Manager as the platform's most critical engagement surface requiring evolution over time
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: works-004 (Use Repetitive Rituals to Contain Active-Lease Anxiety) + ds-ui-1830-006 (Stay Cycle Ritual Card). The three-beat ritual cadence (arrival, cleaning photos, micro-review) provides Freudian order that contains the host's recurring anxiety about the stranger in their space.
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: works-004 (Stays Manager Complexity Ratchet) + ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager with Complexity Ratchet). The Stays Manager must evolve across three lifecycle phases (orientation, rhythm, reflection) to prevent Csikszentmihalyi's boredom zone from setting in by mid-lease.
convergent_themes.implication: Both runs converge on the Stays Manager as the highest-frequency, highest-stakes engagement surface. But they prescribe complementary temporal strategies: Run A wants PREDICTABLE REPETITION (same layout, same ritual, same structure every week) to contain host anxiety. Run B wants PROGRESSIVE EVOLUTION (escalating complexity matched to growing guest skill) to prevent guest boredom. The resolution: the HOST-facing Stays Manager should be ritualistically consistent (Freud), while the GUEST-facing Stays Manager should evolve within a stable skeleton (Flow). This is not a contradiction -- it reflects the fundamentally different psychological needs of each side of the marketplace.

convergent_themes.theme: Messaging as the most important intermediate action between passive evaluation and formal commitment
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: L0 journey-context evaluation phase identifies that 'trust between marketplace participants reduces the felt cost of instinctual sacrifice.' The cross-activation framework from user stories: 'When a guest messages a host, that is not just UX convenience -- it is the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform.'
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: works-005 (Cross-Activation Events as Conversational Interactions) + ds-ui-1831-003 (Conversational Message Composer). Messaging is the intermediate challenge (A2-to-A3 bridge) that prevents the guest from stalling between passive evaluation and overwhelming proposal creation.
convergent_themes.implication: Both runs identify messaging as the highest cross-activation story. Run A frames it from the host side: a message from a guest is evidence of civilizational compliance (the guest is approaching through structured channels, not as a random stranger). Run B frames it from the guest side: messaging is the flow-enabling intermediate challenge that builds confidence before the higher-stakes proposal. The Conversational Message Composer (ds-ui-1831-003) is validated by both lenses as a critical marketplace component.

convergent_themes.theme: Authentication and context disruption as a primary engagement destroyer
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: L0 onboarding phase: 'Authentication should be invisible until it matters' is interpreted as Freudian insight -- civilizational demands should be hidden until the host is already psychologically committed enough that withdrawal costs exceed compliance costs.
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: Cross-phase pattern: 'Concentration is repeatedly broken by system-imposed interruptions.' Flow Ch 4: concentration is one of four necessary conditions, and authentication redirects are 'stimulus overinclusion' that destroys the guest's flow state at moments of highest engagement.
convergent_themes.implication: Both frameworks explain WHY inline authentication matters -- not just as a UX convenience but as a structural requirement for sustaining engagement. Freud: premature demands trigger instinctual revolt. Flow: context switches shatter concentration. Implementation: authentication must use inline modals that preserve the current context, triggered only by high-intent actions (messaging, proposing), never by passive browsing.

convergent_themes.theme: Pause/reversibility as a structural retention mechanism
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: works-002 (Preserve Reversibility to Contain the Revolt Against Civilization) + L0 cross-phase pattern 'The Pause Principle.' Freud identifies two types of freedom-seeking (civilized revolt vs. primitive autonomy); pause accommodates both without forcing permanent exit.
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: behaves-002 (Contextual Continuity Preservation) preserves search state, scroll position, and filter selections across in-session transitions. The Flow lens adds concentration preservation as the justification.
convergent_themes.implication: Run A addresses macro-reversibility (pause vs. delete at the listing level) while Run B addresses micro-reversibility (state preservation across context switches). Together they prescribe reversibility at every temporal scale: within-session (Flow's concentration preservation), between-sessions (save-and-resume), and across-lifecycle (pause instead of delete). The combined prescription is: never destroy user investment at any scale.

convergent_themes.theme: Dashboard urgency hierarchy as a universal platform pattern
convergent_themes.run_a_evidence: communicates-004 (Urgency-First Dashboard as Civilizational Order System) + ds-ui-1830-003 (Host Dashboard Urgency-First Action Panel). Three tiers: action required, status updates, background information. Fixed position every visit.
convergent_themes.run_b_evidence: ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager) uses a three-zone architecture: action band (top), main content (middle), reference footer (bottom). Action items surface first, collapsing when empty.
convergent_themes.implication: Both runs independently derive a three-zone dashboard architecture with urgency at the top. Run A's host dashboard and Run B's guest Stays Manager share the same structural pattern: action required first, content second, reference third. This convergence from host and guest perspectives confirms three-zone urgency-first as a platform-wide design standard, not a role-specific solution.

divergent_themes.theme: Temporal strategy for the Stays Manager: repetitive consistency vs. progressive evolution
divergent_themes.run_a_position: The host Stays Manager should use identical layout every visit. Freud's 'order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' ds-ui-1830-006 (Stay Cycle Ritual Card) uses the exact same three-beat structure for every stay cycle. The host needs predictability to contain recurring anxiety about the stranger in their space.
divergent_themes.run_b_position: The guest Stays Manager should evolve across three lifecycle phases (orientation weeks 1-3, rhythm weeks 4-9, reflection weeks 10-13). Csikszentmihalyi: 'One cannot enjoy doing the same thing at the same level for long.' ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager) changes content weekly within a stable skeleton.
divergent_themes.resolution_recommendation: No conflict exists because these address different sides of the marketplace. The HOST Stays Manager should prioritize Freudian order (ritual consistency, predictable ritual cards, identical layout every visit) because the host's primary psychological need is anxiety containment. The GUEST Stays Manager should prioritize Flow's complexity ratchet (evolving content within a stable skeleton) because the guest's primary psychological need is sustained engagement. Both share the stable skeleton (three-zone architecture); they differ in how content within the skeleton evolves.

divergent_themes.theme: Review frequency: per-stay micro-reviews vs. batched narrative reviews
divergent_themes.run_a_position: ds-ui-1830-006 (Stay Cycle Ritual Card) includes a micro-review prompt as the third beat of every stay ritual. Freud's repetition-compulsion justifies this: the review is part of the civilizational order that contains host anxiety. The host needs regular evidence that the guest is respecting the arrangement.
divergent_themes.run_b_position: The existing library element (Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points) warns against per-stay review prompts due to fatigue. But behaves-004 (Stays Manager Complexity Ratchet) proposes one-tap micro-reviews during the rhythm phase. L6 contradiction flagged: Kahneman says fewer reviews preserve cognitive resources; Flow says more engagement opportunities prevent boredom.
divergent_themes.resolution_recommendation: Adopt a hybrid: 3-point narrative reviews (existing library pattern, at weeks 4, midpoint, and final) as the primary review mechanism for BOTH host and guest. Add optional one-tap micro-ratings (single 5-point scale, no text, no expansion unless initiated) for the HOST's stay ritual card as confirmation that the civilizational contract is holding. These micro-ratings should never feel mandatory or accumulate as unaddressed tasks. They serve different purposes: the host's micro-rating is anxiety containment (Freud), not engagement escalation (Flow).

divergent_themes.theme: Phase coverage emphasis: pre-commitment vs. post-commitment journey
divergent_themes.run_a_position: Run A (host) provides strongest coverage at listing_creation (9 elements), proposal_mgmt (9 elements), active_lease (11 elements), and retention (8 elements). The Freud lens emphasizes the post-commitment journey -- how the host sustains civilizational participation after the initial sacrifice.
divergent_themes.run_b_position: Run B (guest) provides strongest coverage at search (12 elements), listing_evaluation (11 elements), proposal_creation (10 elements), and active_lease (12 elements). The Flow lens emphasizes the pre-commitment journey -- how the guest maintains flow through the decision chain.
divergent_themes.resolution_recommendation: The coverage patterns are complementary, not contradictory. Run A fills gaps in the host post-commitment journey (retention gets the biggest upgrade, from weakest phase to 'strong'). Run B fills gaps in the guest pre-commitment journey (search and listing evaluation get the richest treatment). Combined, they provide strong coverage across both journeys. The remaining gap: acceptance and move-in have thin coverage in both runs.

divergent_themes.theme: Negotiation framing: gatekeeping vs. collaborative game
divergent_themes.run_a_position: The host experiences negotiation as 'vigilant gatekeeping' (feels-004). The counter-proposal is a controlled assertion of remaining autonomy: 'I accept this stranger, but on my terms.' The emphasis is on the host's power to modify terms.
divergent_themes.run_b_position: The guest should experience negotiation as collaborative agon -- 'seeking together' (feels-005). ds-ui-1831-005 (Collaborative Negotiation Comparison Card) provides market calibration data and a 'Suggest a change' option that transforms the binary accept/reject into a skilled game.
divergent_themes.resolution_recommendation: Both framings are valid for their respective sides. The HOST sees the counter-proposal interface as an empowerment tool (they are the gatekeeper making an informed decision). The GUEST sees the negotiation comparison card as a collaborative tool (they are a participant in a fair exchange). The platform should present the SAME underlying data differently to each side: the host sees 'Adjust terms' as an exercise of authority; the guest sees 'Suggest a change' as a collaborative move. Market calibration data should be available to both sides to prevent information asymmetry.

divergent_themes.theme: Token palette: purple production vs. warm neutral tokens.json
divergent_themes.run_a_position: All 7 UI elements reference the production style guide's purple palette (#31135D primary, rgb(109,49,194) secondary, rgb(252,250,255) off-white). L6 explicitly flags tokens.json as outdated and recommends treating the production purple palette as authoritative.
divergent_themes.run_b_position: All 7 UI elements also reference the production purple palette. L6 notes the same token drift and recommends reconciliation. Both runs agree tokens.json is stale.
divergent_themes.resolution_recommendation: No contradiction between runs -- both correctly follow the production style guide. The action item is external: tokens.json must be updated to match production CSS variables. Both runs reinforce this as a priority.

fully_addressed.story: Listing cards want more layers (richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators, neighborhood labels, quick actions)
run_b_elements: ds-ui-1831-001 (Progressive Density Listing Card with three-tier hover system)

fully_addressed.story: Messaging before proposals is a natural step (park analogy -- check availability before committing)
run_b_elements: ds-ui-1831-003 (Conversational Message Composer with host profile, suggested questions, response time)

fully_addressed.story: Completion percentage is a good host nudge (visible progress indicator on listing card)
run_a_elements: ds-ui-1830-002 (Listing Wizard Progress Card with completion bar, step checklist, auto-save)

fully_addressed.story: Pause matters more than delete (preserve work, keep the door open)
Urgency should surface first on the dashboard (unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings)
run_a_elements: ds-ui-1830-003 (Host Dashboard Urgency-First Action Panel with amber indicators)
run_b_elements: ds-ui-1831-007 (Evolving Stays Manager action band at top)

fully_addressed.story: Value before the ask -- always (show something useful first, offer to refine after)
run_a_elements: ds-ui-1830-001 (Discovery Earnings Estimator Card -- zero-ask design)
run_b_elements: ds-ui-1831-001 (Progressive Density Listing Card -- rich data without authentication)

fully_addressed.story: Proposal form should pre-populate with listing details (cross-activation: structured proposals activate hosts)
run_a_elements: ds-ui-1830-004 (trust-first architecture on the host review side)
run_b_elements: ds-ui-1831-004 (Pre-Populated Proposal Builder with staggered pre-population animation and host preview)

partially_addressed.story: Authentication should be invisible until it matters (inline auth pop-up, not full-page redirect)
partially_addressed.gap: Both runs identify this as critical (Run A: Freudian premature demand; Run B: Flow concentration disruption) but neither produces a dedicated UI element for the inline auth modal itself. The principle is embedded in multiple elements (Run B's contextual continuity preservation, Run A's authentication-as-invisible-civilizational-demand) but no run designs the actual auth component.

partially_addressed.story: The map should feel alive (transit stops, landmarks, real-time context)
partially_addressed.gap: ds-ui-1831-002 (Living Map with Proximity Feedback) addresses the alive-map story with pin proximity scaling, neighborhood boundaries, and transit labels. However, it is a search-phase component only. The user stories imply the map should also serve listing evaluation (neighborhood context on the listing page), which is not addressed.

partially_addressed.story: Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests (trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure)
partially_addressed.gap: Run A's ds-ui-1830-004 places trust signals (verification, lease history, rating) above proposal terms on the host side. Run B's communicates-003 (Trust Information Architecture) distributes trust signals across guest-facing phases. But no UI element specifically designs the review display component or the trust badge component itself -- trust is addressed architecturally but not as a standalone buildable element.

partially_addressed.story: Proposal directly from search card is premature -- people need to open the listing first (Probably Not True section)
partially_addressed.gap: Run B's listing_evaluation analysis explicitly validates this: 'There is no intermediate action between passive reading and full proposal commitment -- the challenge jump is too large.' The Progressive Density Card (ds-ui-1831-001) adds a Message Host action in the drawer tier but intentionally does NOT add a proposal action. However, the explicit prohibition is principle-level only, not enforced in a UI constraint.

not_addressed.story: Send email to host -- Rod skipped this one (not needed, messaging covers the intent)
not_addressed.reason: Correctly not addressed. Both runs align with Rod's assessment that in-platform messaging supersedes email. Run B's ds-ui-1831-003 (Conversational Message Composer) makes this explicit by designing messaging as a social flow activity that keeps communication on-platform.

not_addressed.story: Upfront AI logistics prompt -- users probably want to see something first (Probably Not True section)
not_addressed.reason: Correctly not addressed. Both runs align with Rod's pushback. Run A's Freudian analysis explicitly identifies premature information requests as 'civilizational demands that violate the pleasure principle.' Run B's Flow analysis frames sign-up gates as 'the paramount reality of everyday browsing' that must be avoided.

not_addressed.story: An experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action (cross-activation framework)
not_addressed.reason: This cross-activation pattern is referenced in both L0 journey contexts as evidence for trust infrastructure but neither run produces a UI element that specifically surfaces an experienced guest's history to a new host. The pattern is implicitly present in Run A's ds-ui-1830-004 (Proposal Review Card shows lease history and rating) but not designed as a first-host-specific experience.

discovery.run_b_elements: 0 (covered by principles but no dedicated UI element)
discovery.gap_notes: Run A provides the Discovery Earnings Estimator Card for hosts. Run B covers discovery at the principle level (works-006, communicates-005, feels-001) but produces no dedicated discovery UI element for guests. The guest discovery landing experience has no buildable component from either run.

evaluation.gap_notes: Evaluation is the weakest phase in both runs. Run A's L0 identifies the comparison-to-alternatives moment as critical but produces no element for it. Run B's L0 does not include a separate evaluation phase (guest journey uses search + listing_evaluation instead). Neither run has a dedicated evaluation UI element.

search.run_b_elements: 2 (ds-ui-1831-001 Progressive Density Listing Card, ds-ui-1831-002 Living Map)
search.gap_notes: Search is guest-only and well-covered by Run B. The Progressive Density Card and Living Map together address the two primary search surfaces (grid and map). No gap.

listing_evaluation.run_a_elements: 0 (host journey does not include listing evaluation)
listing_evaluation.run_b_elements: 1 (ds-ui-1831-003 Conversational Message Composer bridges evaluation to proposal)
listing_evaluation.gap_notes: Run B's Message Composer serves as the intermediate action between evaluation and proposal. But no element addresses the listing page itself -- the layout, information hierarchy, or trust signal placement on the guest-facing listing detail page. The listing page design remains a gap.

listing_creation.gap_notes: Run A's Wizard Progress Card addresses the dashboard-level view of listing creation progress. But the 6-step wizard itself (the screens within each step) has no dedicated UI element from either run. The wizard progress card is the external view; the internal wizard experience is uncovered.

pricing.run_a_elements: 1 (ds-ui-1830-002 extends to pricing as wizard step 4)
pricing.gap_notes: Pricing is addressed only as one step of the wizard progress card. No element designs the pricing interface itself -- the smart defaults, the market comparison, the fee transparency. Run A's L0 identifies pricing as loaded with instinctual anxiety but produces no pricing-specific element.

proposal_mgmt.run_a_elements: 2 (ds-ui-1830-004 Proposal Review Card, ds-ui-1830-005 Bidirectional Protection Dialog)
proposal_mgmt.gap_notes: Strong combined coverage. Run A covers the HOST side (reviewing and acting on proposals). Run B covers the GUEST side (creating proposals). The Bidirectional Protection Dialog covers the constraint/confirmation moments. Together they address the full proposal lifecycle from creation to review to action.

negotiation.run_a_elements: 0 (counter-proposal is addressed in proposal_mgmt principles but no dedicated negotiation UI)
negotiation.gap_notes: Run B provides the guest-side negotiation interface with side-by-side comparison and market calibration. Run A covers the host counter-proposal as part of proposal_mgmt but does not produce a dedicated host-side negotiation UI element. The host's counter-offer creation interface is uncovered.

acceptance.gap_notes: Run B provides the guest acceptance experience. No host-side acceptance UI exists from either run. The host's experience of a proposal being accepted (seeing that a guest has committed) is uncovered.

move_in.run_b_elements: 0 (ds-ui-1831-006 bridges to move-in but does not design it)
move_in.gap_notes: Move-in is the weakest phase across the entire library (25 of 420 elements) and neither run addresses it with a dedicated UI element. Run B's L0 identifies move-in as critical ('where the physical world interrupts the digital flow channel') and Run B's L6 recommends a dedicated future run for this phase. This is the most significant remaining gap in the system.

active_lease.run_a_elements: 2 (ds-ui-1830-003 Host Dashboard Action Panel covers active_lease, ds-ui-1830-006 Stay Cycle Ritual Card)
active_lease.gap_notes: Strongest combined coverage. Run A addresses the HOST active lease experience (ritual cards for anxiety containment, urgency panel for action prioritization). Run B addresses the GUEST active lease experience (evolving Stays Manager with complexity ratchet). Together with the existing library's 126 active_lease elements, this phase is comprehensively covered.

retention.run_a_elements: 1 (ds-ui-1830-007 Hosting Summary and Retention Continuation Card)
retention.run_b_elements: 0 (guest journey does not include retention as a separate phase)
retention.gap_notes: Run A provides the strongest retention intervention in the library: cumulative earnings display, hosting timeline, one-action continuation. Guest retention (lease renewal, re-booking with same or different host) is not addressed by either run. Run A's retention card is host-only.

library_reinforcement_summary.strongest_reinforcement: Both runs strongly reinforce the Stays Manager design. Run A's works-004 merges with ds-ui-003 (Stays Manager Weekly Dashboard), and Run B's works-004 merges with the same element. The Stays Manager is now validated by five independent theoretical lenses: Kahneman (System 1 dashboard), Eyal (Hook Model for habit formation), Norman (affordances/signifiers), Freud (repetitive rituals for anxiety containment), and Csikszentmihalyi (complexity ratchet for sustained engagement). This makes the Stays Manager the single most theoretically reinforced component in the entire library.
library_reinforcement_summary.most_concerning_contradiction: The review frequency tension between Run B's complexity ratchet (one-tap micro-reviews during each stay cycle in rhythm phase) and the existing library's Batched Review Prompts (explicitly prohibiting per-stay review prompts due to fatigue). Run A's ritual card also includes a per-stay review beat. The resolution requires distinguishing between micro-ratings (one-tap, no text, optional -- acceptable per-stay) and narrative reviews (text-based, effortful -- batch to 3 moments). Both runs' L6 reports independently flag this as the highest-priority contradiction to resolve.
library_reinforcement_summary.token_drift_note: Both runs flag the same ongoing token drift: tokens.json uses warm green accent (#2d5a3d) while production uses purple (#31135D). Both runs correctly reference the production palette. Both L6 reports recommend treating the production style guide as authoritative and updating or deprecating tokens.json. The proposed coral accent (Run B's --accent-coral for save-heart) is flagged as non-canonical by Run B's own L6.
